repnme.cdata!:
Honduras - Third Social Investment Fund;
            and Fourth Social Investment Fund Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment rates the outcome
            moderately satisfactory for the Third Social Investment Fund
            and the Fourth Social Investment Fund projects for Honduras.
            The central objective of Honduran Social investment Fund
            (FHIS) of supporting the government's poverty
            alleviation strategy was relevant and in line with the
            Poverty Reduction Strategy Paper (PRSP) and the Country
            Assistance Strategy (CAS). The assessment rates overall
            sustainability as unlikely for both credits. Although most
            FHIS projects are reported (in project evaluations) to be in
            use, the same evaluations also note that they are often not
            used in full and there were many problems with the quality
            of subprojects and with their maintenance. Overall Bank
            performance was satisfactory with caveats. Bank staff was
            overoptimistic about the possibilities of securing
            maintenance, first by expecting too much from line
            ministries and later by relying too heavily on user
            committees. The experience of the two projects offers three
            lessons: While social funds are attractive for donors and
            can initially be successful in providing remote communities
            access to basic health and educational facilities, the
            experience of the Honduras social fund shows that they are
            not a long-term sustainable solution for providing basic
            infrastructure. Because of the apparent success in its core
            activity of financing basic infrastructure projects, FHIS
            has been and continues to be attractive for donors for
            programs that do not belong to the core activity. FHIS had a
            positive institutional development impact in promoting
            decentralization by helping to strengthen local government
            capacities in project planning and implementation.

repnme.cdata!: Honduras - Third Social Investment Fund Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is satisfactory, and
            sustainability is likely. Among the many lessons drawn from
            the project, it is indicated that because of the Honduran
            Social Investment Fund's (FHIS) autonomy, in the
            management of financial resources, its efficiency is strong,
            attracting highly qualified professionals, who convey strong
            leadership in decision-making, thus strengthening the
            institution. The properly designed management information
            system, facilitated indicators, and monitoring to take
            corrective actions as needed. But an institution designed to
            process infrastructure subprojects, is not easily adapted to
            deal with the social aspects of work, nor social assistance
            projects, thus improvements in the Social Fund's
            capacity to handle social issues, depend on the continuous
            effort of both the borrower, and donors, in providing
            appropriate technical assistance, training, and
            opportunities. These could actually be incorporated as
            elements for social funds programs. But regardless of
            FHIS's outstanding performance to communities,
            particularly in response to Hurricane Mitch's needs,
            the institution took a toll on the efficiency previously
            established. Hence, contingency plans could be developed
            with the Bank, to better face emergency situations.

repnme.cdata!:
Honduras - Third Social Investment Fund
            Project (FHIS Second Stage)

abstracts.cdata!:
The Third Social Investment Fund Project
            (Honduran Social Investment Fund (FHIS) Second Stage) will
            continue to assist the Government in strengthening its
            poverty allevation efforts and in maintaining social
            cohesion, while the Government attempts to regain fiscal
            balance and the line ministries strengthen their
            institutional capacities. It will also support the
            Government's decentralization strategy, development to
            the local contracting industry, the sustainability of
            subprojects, and the targeting of scarce resources in poorer
            areas. To achieve this, it will focus on meeting priority
            social and economic departments, municipalities,
            nongovernmental organizations (NGOs), and communities,
            within the parameters of municipal allocations decided on
            the basis of a poverty targeting formula. The project will
            support FHIS's investment program for a four-year
            period, as well as efforts to establish a better social data
            base and to assist municipalities on environmental matters.
            It will provide for (a) a range of small-scale, social and
            economic infrastructure subprojects; (b) a priority basic
            needs program; (c) a comprehensive program of technical
            assistance to help FHIS overcome some institutional
            weakness; (d) the establishment of a social data mapping
            system and strengthening of the design and implementation of
            national household surveys as the major tools to target the
            poor and to monitor progress of social development programs;
            and (e) subject to trails carried out by FHIS under the
            Environmental Development Project, a small program of
            technical assistance to municipalities in assessing
            environmental issues and in preparing programs for
            corrective action.
